channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Dutch Offer Preview of Net Neutrality
item.description: As with the rules adopted by the F.C.C., the Netherlands demands that wireless and fixed-line broadband providers treat all Internet traffic equally.
item.dc:creator: By MARK SCOTT
item.media:credit: Jasper Juinen/Bloomberg News, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Outside an Apple store in the Netherlands. Two years ago the country mandated that Internet providers treat all traffic equally.

item.title: In China, Suspicions Cloud Trade Dispute Involving Tech Companies
item.description: With both countries wary of the other’s digital espionage, American tech companies are caught in the middle.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ and PAUL MOZUR
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Internet cafe in Huamingzhen, Tianjin, China. American tech companies are caught in a trade conflict between Washington and Beijing.

item.title: Russia and Ukraine Calm Feud Over Natural Gas Payments
item.description: A payment dispute that had been casting a shadow over European energy markets appeared to be winding down on Friday, as both countries agreed to European-brokered negotiations.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Avijit Roy, Bangladeshi-American Writer, Is Killed by Machete-Wielding Assailants
item.description: Avijit Roy was leaving a book fair in the Bangladeshi capital when he was attacked, the police said. His wife was in critical condition from a blow to the head.
item.dc:creator: By JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: The writer Avijit Roy's wife, Rafida Ahmed Bonya, at Dhaka Medical College hospital on Friday after she received a blow to her head from unidentified assailants.

item.title: Cameron Defends British Security Services Over ‘Jihadi John’
item.description: Prime Minister David Cameron spoke after disclosures that a man who posed in ISIS videos of the murder of Western hostages was known to British intelligence.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Finding Gaza Unbearable, Artist Creates Her Own World in One Room
item.description: Nidaa Badwan’s project is called “100 Days of Solitude” in homage to Gabriel García Márquez’s novel, though her isolation has lasted much longer.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Wissam Nassar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nidaa Badwan in her room in Deir al-Balah, Gaza Strip. The wall behind her is covered with egg cartons.

item.title: Opinion: The Next Great Migration
item.description: Why don’t more black Americans move abroad?
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS CHATTERTON WILLIAMS
item.media:credit: Gisèle Freund/IMEC, Fonds MCC, Dist. RMN-Grand Palais, via Art Resource, NY
item.media:description: The American author Richard Wright at the Jardin du Luxembourg in Paris in 1958.

item.title: Liberia’s President Urges U.S. to Continue Ebola Aid
item.description: President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf of Liberia praised the American efforts to fight the virus, which have helped to nearly eliminate new cases.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf of Liberia met with President Obama at the White House on Friday.

item.title: Servando Gómez, Mexican Drug Lord Known as La Tuta, Is Captured
item.description: Mr. Gómez, who led the Knights Templar gang, vowed in taunting videos not to be taken alive. He was arrested at a hot dog stand, news reports said.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Lens Blog: Back in the U.S.S.R.
item.description: Arthur Tress’s forays into his archives have already graced Lens with classic views of San Francisco. His latest offering comes from a 1967 trip to Russia, where he chronicled daily life amid Soviet pageantry.
item.dc:creator: By EVELYN NIEVES
item.media:description: A group of schoolchildren visiting the Field of Mars war memorial.

item.title: Pakistani Officials Issue Arrest Warrants Over Refusals of Polio Vaccine
item.description: Police officials in the northwest province of Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa said they had issued hundreds of arrest warrants for parents who have refused to vaccinate their children.
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN

item.title: ‘Jihadi John’ From ISIS Execution Videos Was Under Watch by British Intelligence
item.description: The man, identified as Mohammed Emwazi, came to the attention of the authorities in 2009, when they thought he was going to fight with Al Shabab.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Mohammed Emwazi as identified in a beheading video.

item.title: Israeli Utility to Stop Disrupting Electricity in West Bank
item.description: The state-owned electric company, which briefly reduced power on two days this week, has reached a deal with the Israeli government to help offset what it is owed.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Spain Arrests 8 on Suspicion of Fighting for Rebels in Ukraine
item.description: Those arrested, the Interior Ministry said, recently returned to Spain after going to Ukraine last year to join pro-Russian troops around Luhansk and Donetsk.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Cuba’s Spot on U.S. Terror List Gums Up Restoration of Relations
item.description: Some Republicans openly oppose the removal of the island nation from the list of countries that sponsor terrorism, while Cuban officials demand it as a prerequisite for ties.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
item.media:description: Roberta S. Jacobson, the assistant secretary of state for Western Hemisphere affairs, center, in Havana last month for talks on restoring relations with Cuba.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Beijing Courts Address the Right to Criticize Public Figures
item.description: Two recent court rulings, and Kong Qingdong’s refusal to comply with one of them, have prompted a debate about the extent to which public figures can be held accountable for their statements, and the right of ordinary citizens to criticize such figures.
item.dc:creator: By PATRICK BOEHLER

item.title: After Washington, Petraeus Is Under Radar, but Not Out of Spotlight
item.description: Facing an inquiry that could send him to prison, David H. Petraeus, the former C.I.A. chief, keeps a lower profile as White House adviser, college teacher and partner at a private equity firm.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG

item.title: Migrants Said to Be Missing After Small Boat Overturns Near Macau
item.description: The Chinese news media reported that 15 people were missing, and the Macau authorities said rescuers were searching for survivors.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Hong Kong Woman Sentenced to 6 Years for Abusing Indonesian Maid
item.description: Law Wan-tung subjected her live-in servant, Erwiana Sulistyaningsih, to various forms of abuse for months, according to testimony at her trial.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Hopeful Signs of Recovery for the World’s Rarest Big Cat
item.description: Thanks to conservation efforts in Russia and China, the Amur leopard population has increased dramatically, though with only a few dozen in the wild, the species still faces threats to its survival.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A 2013 image of an Amur leopard taken by a camera trap in northeast China.
